journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Dynamical strength and design optimization of pipe-joint system under pressure impact load

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Engineering Mechanics, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi’an, People’s Republic of China
2School of Civil Engineering, Xuzhou Institute of Technology, Xuzhou, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Department of Engineering Mechanics, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi’an 710072, People’s Republic of China. email: yongshouliu@nwpu.edu.cn

abstract.p: This article is focused on the dynamical strength analysis and design optimization of a pipe-joint system. A three-dimensional model of a fuel pipe-joint system is established and the strength and dynamic analysis of the system under the pressure impact load is analysed. In order to avoid dangerous forced vibrations or resonance, and to lower vibration level, the clamps’ numbers and locations are optimized. The results show that: (a) under the pressure impact load, near the T-branch pipe, clamps and elbows, the pipe system’s failure can easily occur; and (2) the numbers and locations of clamps of pipe-joint system can be optimized and the optimized pipe-joint system has better anti-vibration ability.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Hydraulic or fuel pipeline systems are usually composed of pipes, joints, pumps, oil-filters, and so on. They are dominant systems of airplanes, and play vital roles for airplanes safety and reliability. For hydraulic and fuel pipeline systems, investigations have shown that pipeline system’s failures caused by hydraulic pressure fluctuation impact are about 30 percent among all airplanes’ failures [1].

The pipelines vibration caused by hydraulic pressure fluctuation impact has been researched by many scholars. Paidoussis and Li [2] systemically researched the dynamic problem of pipes conveying fluid. They studied the rich dynamic behaviours of a pipe conveying fluid. Their work involved the dynamics of pipes with different supports pipes (such as supported ends pipes, cantilevered pipes, and continuously flexible pipes), the incompressible and compressible flow, the steady and unsteady flow, and linear, non-linear, and chaotic dynamics. The literature [3] presents a slowly-varying parameter conception about pipeline forced vibrations, and it proposes the engineering analysed method of fluid-structure interaction (FSI). When pipelines’ natural frequencies are close to frequencies of pressure pulsation and hydraulic pressure pumps, the resonance vibration of FSI can be easily initiated. Hyde et al. [4] investigated the residual hoop stresses in pressurized pipes caused by long external indentations and the subsequent stress variations caused by internal pressure fluctuations. Using experimental method, Bagchi et al. [5] studied the pressure fluctuations and flow perturbations in air flow through vibrating pipes. Qing et al. [6] carried out a hydraulic test for studying orifice-induced random wall pressure fluctuations and vibration in a pipeline.

To reduce the pipeline systems’ failure, some new-style pipes and joints, such as Shape Memory Alloy (SMA) joints, are used and the strength, dynamic analysis, and optimization of the pipe-joint system are being studied. Often, SMA is used as vibration absorbers to reduce the vibration [7, 8]. It is also used as a component of some smart structure [9]. In pipe-joint system, SMA joints are used in aircraft hydraulic or fuel pipeline systems. Using SMA joints, Xu and Song [10] proposed adaptive control of vibration wave propagation in cylindrical shells. Jee et al. [11] considered that the conventional method that is composed of deformation of SMAs coupling below Ms (Martensite phase-change start) temperature, installation of the deformed coupling pipes to be joined and heating above Af (Austenite phase-change finish) temperature. To remove the difficulty caused by errors of pipe size, they proposed an alternative method of pipe joining using SMAs. Wang et al. [12] studied the reverse martensitic transformation behaviour in a SMA pipe-joint.
The work in this article is focused on the dynamical strength analysis and design optimization of a pipe-joint system with SMA joints. There are two parts of optimization processes.

The first part is clamp’s number optimization. The basic idea of the dynamical strength analysis and clamp’s number optimization was shown in Fig. 1. First, the three-dimensional (3D) model of fuel pipe-joint system was established. Second, the strength and dynamic analysis of the original pipe-joint system under the pressure impact load is analysed. According to the results, the maximum mode displacement points of the system can be obtained. Then, other clamps can be added at these points. Finally, in order to avoid dangerous forced vibrations or resonance, and lower vibration level, the clamps’ numbers are optimized. To get higher first-order natural frequency, some clamps’ locations are defined as designed variables. Through control of the distance between each elbow and the clamp, the clamp's number is optimized. In the process of optimization, if the distance of the two, adjacent clamps d is smaller than a given small value d0 (d0 is determined by the design engineers according to the clamps’ location on the pipe and the location\space allowed by aircraft structure). In this article, d0=20mm, one of these two clamps can be deleted; while if the distance of the two adjacent clamps d is larger than this given small value d0, the optimization can be finished and the clamps’ number optimization scheme can be obtained. Fig. 1
The basic idea of the clamps’ number optimization of pipe-joint system
The second part of optimization processes is clamp’s location optimization. In order to get higher first-order natural frequency avoiding dangerous resonance, some clamps’ location is optimized.
Through two parts of optimization processes, the optimized clamps’ locations and numbers scheme can be obtained.

sec.title: 2.1 Analysed model
sec.p:
The analysed model of the joint-pipe system of some airplane fuel pipeline system is shown in Fig. 2. The system is mainly composed of SMAs joints, pipes, T-branch pipe, and so on. Fig. 2
3D model of the joint-pipe system

This analysed model is built in expert CAD software, Solid works [13]. A valve is connected with the left end of the model, and the model’s two right ends are connected with pumps, respectively. Nine SMAs joints (numbered 1–9) connect all parts, and all joints’ locations are also shown in Fig. 2. There are 16 (numbered 1–16) clamps of the original system. After the dynamic analysis, the new five (numbered 17–21) clamps are added. These clamps are also shown in Fig. 2.

In FEM software ANSYS, eight-node linear hexahedral elements (C3D8) are chosen to mesh the whole structure. The meshed model of the typical T-branch pipe is shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3
T-branch pipe’s meshed model

sec.title: 2.2 Material parameters
sec.p: The material of joints is Ti-50.8 wt%Ni. Its elastic modulus is 61.2 GPa, Poisson’s ratio is υ = 0.3, the density is ρ = 5.6 × 103 kg/m3 and the critical damping coefficient is 0.01. The drive energy for phase change and inverse phase change of the martensite is FC, A → M = 22.5 × 106 J/m3, FC, M → A = 12.5 × 106 J/m3, respectively. For the details of the Ti-50.8 wt%Ni superelastic model, please refer to reference [14].
The material of pipe is stainless steel. Its elastic modulus is 184 GPa, Poisson’s ratio is υ = 0.3, the density ρ = 8.7 × 103 kg/m3 and the critical damping coefficient is 0.01.

sec.title: 3 CONDITIONS AND PARAMETERS FOR THE OPTIMIZATION
sec.p: In order to avoid dangerous forced vibrations or resonance, and lower vibration level, the system’s natural frequency and vibration level should be controlled during pipeline design. Natural frequencies of the pipe-joint system should not be close to frequencies of pressure pulsation or hydraulic pressure pumps. Otherwise, the resonance vibration of FSI can be easily initiated. The displacements and static/dynamic stresses of the key parts of pipe-joint system, such as joints, T-branch pipes and bends, should be reduced. When basic structure of the pipe-joint system is defined and the materials and the boundary conditions are known, the number and location of clamps are optimized to avoid the structure’s dangerous forced vibrations and reduce the structure’s dynamic stresses. The optimization is carried out using the multi-Sequential Unconstrained Minimization Technique (SUMT) method in MSC. Nastran software.
All the conditions and parameters for dynamical analyses and design optimization are defined as follows.

sec.title: 3.1 Boundary conditions and loads for dynamical analyses
sec.p: When the dynamic strength of the pipe-joint system is analysed, at three ends, all freedoms are confined. There are 16 clamps (numbered 1–16) in original pipe-joint system. Their locations are shown in Fig. 2.

Two local coordinate systems are set near pumps. Interfaces between joints and pipes are completely glued. The pipeline system is analysed under pressure impact loads. Because loading time is less than 1 s, the dynamic response should be calculated. Within 1 s, the pressure load (P = 1.5 MPa) is completely applied onto the internal pipe wall, and the loading curve is shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4
Pressure impact loading curve

sec.title: 3.2 Clamp’s number optimization
sec.p: Because the pipe-joints system is complex, the mechanism of the effect of the clamps’ number on the frequencies is not expressed by the analytic equation, so here the clamp’s number optimization is a selective preference method guided by the mathematic principles. That is to say, to avoid dangerous resonance and to lower the vibration level, some clamp’s number optimization schemes are obtained, and all these schemes is satisfied with the frequency constraints (the first-order natural frequency of the pipe-joint system is no less than 150 Hz) and the distance of the two adjacent clamps requirement (the distance of the two adjacent clamps d is no smaller than a given small value d0). These schemes are compared and the scheme containing the least number of clamps are chosen as the clamp’s number optimization scheme.

The procedure of the clamp’s number optimization is as follows. First, according to the results of the strength and dynamic analysis of the pipe-joint system under the pressure impact load, five clamps (numbered 17–21) are added at the maximum mode displacement points (Fig. 2). In this time, the number of clamps changed 1 from 6 (numbered 1–16) to 21(numbered 1–21). The locations of 11 clamps (numbered 2–7, numbered 17–21) of all the 21 clamps are optimized and chosen. Second, the clamp’s location is optimized. In this optimization procedure, the designed variables are defined as the locations of 11 clamps, and objective function is the largest first-order frequency. The optimization algorithm is the SUMT method and the search algorithm is the steepest descent method and the detailed procedure is described in section 3.4. Third, after the clamp’s location optimization, all the distances of the two adjacent clamps of are determined. If this distance d is lager than a given small value d0, one scheme of the clamp’s number optimization is obtained. If this distance d is smaller than a given small value d0, one of these two adjacent clamps is deleted, and one scheme of the clamp’s number optimization is also obtained. At last, all the schemes are compared, and the pipe-joint system with the least clamps and satisfied with the natural frequency constraint (the first-order natural frequency ω1>150Hz) is chosen as the optimization scheme of the clamp’s number optimization.

sec.title: 3.2.1 Natural frequency constraint
sec.p: The first-order natural frequency of the original pipe-joint system is 119 Hz. According to the design requirement and avoiding the dangerous resonance, the first-order natural frequency of the optimized model should be increased from 119 to 150 Hz or more. Therefore, in the clamp’s number optimization procedure, the constraint is the first-order natural frequency of the pipe-joint system is no less than 150 Hz.

sec.title: 3.2.2 Designed variables
sec.p:
In the clamp’s number optimization procedure, the designed variables are defined as the number of the clamps n. The model analysis results of the original pipe-joint system show that near the number 1–8 clamps the pipes have larger deformation. Especially, the vibration deformation easily occurs at elbow pipes near the number 4 clamps. In order to get the least of the number of clamps, based on above dynamical analysis and engineering experience, the locations of 11 clamps (numbered 2–7, numbered 17–21) of all the 21 clamps are optimized. Therefore, the designed variable n is from 0 to 11 (Table 1). Table 1
Designed variables of two optimized types
Designed type Clamp’s number Clamp’s location
Designed variables n (x1,x2,x3,x4)
Original value 11 (300,100,100,150)
Upper limit 11 (600,600,500,300)
Lower limit 0 (0,0,0,0)

sec.title: 3.2.3 Optimization objective
sec.p: The dynamical design for aircraft pipe-joint system requires that the design should satisfy two principles. One is avoiding dangerous forced vibrations and the other is reducing vibration levels. In the clamp’s number optimization procedure, the optimization objective is the number of clamps should be minimized while the first-order natural frequency of the pipe-joint system is no less than 150 Hz.

sec.title: 3.3 Clamp’s location optimization
sec.p: After the clamp’s number optimization, there are 16 clamps and the first-order natural frequency of the pipe-joint system is 151.52 Hz. In order to get higher first-order natural frequency to avoid dangerous resonance, according to engineering require, the four (clamp 17, clamp 3, clamp 4, and clamp 20) clamps’ location are optimized. In process of optimization, the designed variables are the four clamps’ locations (x1,x2,x3,x4) (listed in Table 1). This four clamps’ locations (x1,x2,x3,x4) are the distance from each elbow pipe to the clamp (Fig. 2). In Table 1, unit of variables (x1,x2,x3,x4) is millimeter and the original value of the designed variables (x1,x2,x3,x4) can be obtained when the clamp’s number optimization is finished. The upper and lower limits can be obtained by the pipe’s structure and engineering experience. In clamp’s location optimization, the optimization objective is the highest first-order natural frequency.

sec.title: 3.4 Optimization algorithm and search algorithm
sec.p: The optimization algorithm is the SUMT method and the search algorithm is the steepest descent method. The multi-SUMT method is used in the clamp’s location optimization. This method has the common advantages of SUMT-external point method and SUMT-interior method. At the same time, because easy program and wide scope of application, the multi-SUMT method is widely used in engineering practice.

sec.title: 3.4.1 Optimization algorithm
sec.p: In fact, each iteration process of the clamp’s number optimization is a single-clamp’s location optimization. The procedure and method for the clamp’s number optimization (each iteration process) and the clamp’s location optimization is as follows.
The mathematical model is (1)

Here, xi is the location of the ith clamp; x the clamps’ location set; n the number of the designed variables; ω1 the first-order frequency; f(x) the objective function; xi l and xi u the lower limit value and the upper limit value, respectively.
To construct the mixed penalty function, let (2)
Therefore, the optimization problem with constraints can be treated as the below optimization problem without constraints. (3)

Here, B(x) is the wall-function item constructed by the interior point method, while x is satisfied with those inequality constraints; p(x) the penalty-function item constructed by the external point method while x is not satisfied with those inequality constraints; r penalty factor. B(x) and p(x) can be written as (4) Here (5)
The value of the penalty factor r can be determined by (6)
In equation (6), usually c∈[0.1,0.25], and υ* is one estimated value of the optimum solution f(x*) of the optimization problem (1) with constraints.

sec.title: 3.4.2 Search algorithm
sec.p:
The compute procedure of the steepest descent method, in this article, can be shown in the following steps.
Step 1: Choose an initial value x(o), the parameter r0=|υ*|100 and c=0.1, and compute precision ɛi=10-2,i=1,2,3.
Step 2: Let k=1, and x(k-1) is initial point, use the steepest descent method to solve the optimization problem minF(x,rk) without constraints; let m=0,X(m)=x(k-1).
Step 3: Compute the gradient ∇F(X(m)).
Step 4: If ‖∇F(X(m))‖<ɛ1, the optimum solution X(m) of minF(x,rk) can be obtained, that is x(k), then go to the step 5; or else, use precision one-dimensional search to get one minimal point λm of the ϕ(λ)=F(X(m)-λ∇F(X(m))), and this minimal point λm must be satisfied with F(X(m)-λ∇F(X(m)))<F(X(m)). Then, let X(m+1)=X(m)-λm∇F(X(m)) and m=m+1, go back to step 3.
Step 5: If x(k) is satisfied with constraint ‖x(k)-x(k-1)‖<ɛ2,‖f(x(k))-f(x(k-1))‖<ɛ3, the iterative operation is end, and x(k) is approximate optimum solution; or else, let rk+1=rkc,k=k+1 and go back to step 2.

sec.title: 4.1 Mode analysis
sec.p:
For the original model, its first five modes and natural frequencies are computed. Figures 5 and 6 illustrate the first- and second-order mode of the original model. It is observed that in the segment of clamps 1–8, the pipe has larger deformation. The vibration deformation easily occurs at elbow pipes near the number 4 clamps. Fig. 5
First-order mode of the original system (first-order natural frequency 119 Hz) Fig. 6
Second-order mode of the original system (second-order natural frequency 178 Hz)

sec.title: 4.2 Transient response analysis
sec.p:
Figures 7 and 8 show the stress results of the original system under the pressure impact load at loading time t=1.0s. It can be seen that the maximum dynamical stresses locate near the T-branch pipe. The stresses in the number 4 clamp and elbow pipe are relatively lower. At loading time t=1.0s and the pressure load P=1.5 MPa, the maximum Von Mises stress is 86 MPa. The results also implied that near the T-branch pipe, clamps and elbow pipes, the system’s failure can easily occur. Fig. 7
Stress distribution of original system Fig. 8
Stress distribution of T-branch pipe

Figure 9 shows the stresses of nine joints in the original system under the pressure impact load at loading time t=1.0s. From this figure, it can be seen that the joints 3, 4, and 7 near the T-branch pipe have higher stresses than other joints. The number 4 joint has the maximum Von Mises stress (18 MPa) (Fig. 10). It implied that the SMA joints near the T-branch pipe are easily failed and stress concentration of its inner interface is serious. Fig. 9
Stress distribution of all joints Fig. 10
Stress distribution of number 4 joint

The stress versus time curve of node 1444 is illustrated in Fig. 11. It is observed that with the loading time increase, the amplitude value of the stress of node 1444 becomes smaller, and at last it becomes a fixed value. The reason is that with the loading time increase, the energy of the system is dissipated. Fig. 11
Stress versus time curve at node 1444 (signed in Fig. 7)

Figure 12 shows the acceleration distribution results of original system under the pressure impact load at loading time t=1.0s. It can be seen that the joints at the segment of clamps 1–8 has a higher acceleration. Near the clamp 14, the acceleration value is also relatively high, and the maximum acceleration is 25 m/s2. It implied that dynamical optimization of number and location at the segment of clamps 1–8 can easily succeed. Fig. 12
Acceleration distribution of original system

sec.title: 4.3.1 Clamp’s number optimization and discussion
sec.p:
The first five-order natural frequencies of optimizing system, the clamps’ total number and designed variable n are shown in Table 2. It can be observed that in order to satisfy with the natural frequency constraint and optimization objective, the clamps’ total number is 16, and the first-order natural frequency of the system is 151.52 Hz. After clamps’ number optimization, the first-order mode of the optimized system is shown in Fig. 13. It implied that the anti-vibration ability of the optimized system is improved. Fig. 13
First-order mode of the optimized joint system (after number of clamps optimization) Table 2

sec.title: 4.3.2 Clamp’s location optimization and discussion
sec.p:
Figure 14 shows the optimized curves of designed variables x1, x2, x3, and x4. It can be seen that the anti-vibration ability of the optimized system is improved, and the first natural frequency of our optimized system is increased from 151.52 to 194.7 Hz. The optimized variables x1, x2, x3 and x4 are 450, 40, 260, and 40 mm, respectively. The 16 clamps’ location and the first-order mode of optimized pipe-joint system are shown in Figs 15 and 16, respectively. After number and location optimization, the first-order natural frequency of the system is 194.7 Hz and the maximum Von Mises stress of pipes and joints are smaller than the design values. The dynamical strength and airplane performance of optimized pipe-joint system is improved. Fig. 14
Optimized curve of designed variables (x1,x2,x3,x4) Fig. 15
16 clamps’ location of the optimized pipe-joint system (after number of clamps and location optimization) Fig. 16
First-order mode of the optimized pipe-joint system (after number of clamps and location optimization)

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
This article researches the 3D model of pipeline systems under pressure impact loads. Strength and dynamic analysis of the pipeline system is analysed, and clamps’ locations and numbers are optimized. The following results are summarized.
Under the pressure impact load, near the T-branch pipe, clamps and elbow, pipes system’s failure can easily occur. In particular, near the T-branch pipe, the joint can be easily failed, and stress concentration of its inner interface is higher. Therefore, it should be paid more attention to these parts.
Based on the dynamical analysis results, the clamps’ number and locations of pipe-joint system can be optimized. The dynamical strength of the optimized system is improved. The optimized pipe-joint system has better anti-vibration ability.
